intro: Lepidium hyssopifolium, commonly known as Mexican peppergrass, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many edible and economically important plants. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and has small, lance-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy texture. Its flowers are yellow and form in clusters, and it produces small, round pods that contain several seeds. Botanically, it is characterized by its unique leaf arrangement and its ability to thrive in arid environments.
